feed.title: NewsTracker: apple
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Apple Pay coming to Canada?
entry.summary: Apple Inc is planning to launch its electronic payments service in Canada in November, the first international expansion of Apple Pay, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

entry.title: SunPower, Apple to build solar projects in China
Apple Pay Plans to Launch in Canada
entry.summary: A base case for Canadian banks could be in the range of 15 to 25 basis points on credit card transactions to Apple, according to one of those people.

entry.title: Don't plan to line up for Apple Watch next week
entry.summary:
Apple stores have had watches on display since last week, and the company is offering in-person demonstrations for customers who want to try different models.

The market research firm Slice Intelligence estimated nearly 1 million people placed orders on April 10, the first day Apple began accepting them.

entry.title: Don't plan to line up for Apple Watch next week
entry.summary:
Apple, which began accepting advance orders for the watch last week, had previously said it would be "available" for sale in stores on April 24, at least for customers who made reservations to come in for a personal demonstration.

But with supplies limited, Apple's retail chief has told store workers that the watch will continue to be sold only through online orders for at least the next several weeks.

That's a departure from the way the way Apple has launched other new products, such as its popular iPhones, which have been offered for sale in stores to customers who often arrived hours early and lined up outside before the first day of a new release.

entry.title: Don't plan to line up for Apple Watch next week
Apple co-operation with antitrust monitor down 'sharply': report
entry.summary: Representatives for Apple did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

entry.title: Court-appointed monitor says Apple's antitrust cooperation 'sharply declined' in recent months
Court-appointed monitor says Apple's antitrust cooperation 'sharply declined' in recent months
entry.summary: The monitor, Michael Bromwich, says in a report made public Thursday that Apple's cooperation with the monitoring team "sharply declined" this year.

entry.title: Court monitor: Apple antitrust cooperation has 'declined'
entry.summary:
Bromwich was appointed to review the Cupertino, California company's antitrust compliance policies and training after the judge concluded in a case in New York that Apple violated antitrust laws when it entered the e-book market in 2010.

Since then, he said, "Apple's communications with us reverted to the more adversarial tone taken in the first few months of the monitorship, including attempts to prescribe and limit how the monitor should conduct his reviews and write his reports."

Apple's program still lacked an independent antitrust compliance officer and adequate board oversight, he said.

Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., an Apple attorney, told appeals judges in December that Seattle-based Amazon was the monopoly in the e-book market before Apple arrived on the scene.

entry.title: Court monitor: Apple antitrust cooperation has 'declined'
entry.summary: He said Apple's cooperation with his team deteriorated as the company rejected requests to interview business personnel, refused to turn over certain documents and information and only let Bromwich's team look at a small sample of training sessions.

entry.title: Apple Watch will not be available in-store in May: Report
entry.summary: Apple Inc's watches will not be available to buy in-store in May, according to a memo from Apple retail chief Angela Ahrendts, the Telegraph reported.

entry.title: Apple invests in China solar project, US forest conservation
entry.summary: Apple won't necessarily buy paper made from trees on that land, but Jackson said the investment will increase the supply of sustainable wood fiber.

entry.title: Apple invests in China solar project, US forest conservation
entry.summary: Apple is expanding its environmental efforts by investing in a new Chinese solar power project and preserving 36,000 acres of "sustainable" timberland in Maine and North Carolina.

entry.title: Apple invests in China solar project, US forest conservation
entry.summary:
(AP) - In a quest to be more green, Apple says it is investing in Chinese solar power and preserving forests that make environmentally friendly paper.

It's also promising to use more renewable power overseas, where Apple relies heavily on contract manufacturers - and where a top executive acknowledged the company can do more.

The new solar project in China has a capacity of 40 megawatts, which is smaller than some projects Apple has announced in the United States.

By comparison, Apple is spending $850 million for rights to nearly half the output of a 280-megawatt solar facility planned for construction south of Apple's Cupertino, California, headquarters.

That project will produce enough energy to power all of Apple's California offices, a computer center and 52 retail stores.

Still, the Chinese project will produce more than the amount of energy consumed by Apple's 19 corporate offices and 21 retail stores in China and Hong Kong, Jackson said.

entry.title: Apple invests in China solar project, US forest conservation
6% of US adults plan to buy Apple Watch: Poll
entry.summary: "I already have the iPhone, the iPad, pretty much everything that Apple offers," said poll respondent Sefu Grady, a 37-year- old counselor living in Clinton, Mississippi.

entry.title: Exclusive: Six percent of U.S. adults plan to buy Apple Watch - Reuters/Ipsos poll
entry.summary:
The poll showed the watch, marketed by Apple as a high-fashion item as well as a new frontier in technology, appealed to fewer than 4 percent of women compared with 9 percent of men.

Not surprisingly, iPhone owners are more likely to spend money on the new Apple gadget, with about 15 percent saying they planed to buy.

entry.title: Exclusive: Six percent of U.S. adults plan to buy Apple Watch - Reuters/Ipsos poll
entry.summary:
People around the world flocked to Apple stores on April 10 to try on the watches, which go on sale officially on April 24, and online orders quickly outstripped supply, with most customers facing at least a month's wait.

According to the poll, adults aged between 30 and 39 were the most likely buyers, with 13 percent saying they planed to buy an Apple Watch, followed by 10 percent of 18-to-29-year-olds.

entry.title: Apple is facing a very awkward lawsuit
entry.summary: ARTIST Romero Britto is suing Apple Inc. and a design firm in federal court, accusing them of misusing his colour-splashed images and distinctive style in marketing campaigns.

entry.title: Florida artist claims Apple stole his style
IBM teams with Apple on artificial intelligence health program
entry.summary: Under the partnership it will be able to handle data collected using health applications from Apple mobile devices, according to IBM.

entry.title: IBM teams with Apple on artificial intelligence health program
Apple expected to quickly ramp up smartwatch production
entry.summary: However, analysts said Apple could sell between 2.3 million and 4 million watches in the quarter ending June.Apple was widely expected to disclose pre-orders on Monday, following its usual pattern after a product launch.

entry.title: Artist Britto sues Apple, design firm over use of art, style
entry.summary: In fact, when the Apple "Start Something New" campaign appeared, Britto received messages congratulating him, incorrectly, for what appeared to be a new business deal with Apple.

entry.title: Artist Britto sues Apple, design firm over use of art, style
entry.summary: One image, an outstretched hand with colorful designs flowing from a fingertip, was licensed from Craig & Karl by Apple.

entry.title: Artist Britto sues Apple, design firm over use of art, style
entry.summary: After investigating the source of the Apple image, according to the lawsuit, Britto's lawyers noticed apparent similarities between Craig & Karl's work and that of Britto.

entry.title: Artist Britto Sues Apple, Design Firm Over Use of Art, Style
Artist Britto sues Apple, design firm over use of art, style
entry.summary:
The lawsuit seeks unspecified damages from Cupertino, California-based Apple and the design duo Craig Redman of New York and Karl Maier of London, whose company is called Craig & Karl.

Apple's "Start Something New" marketing campaign was cited in the lawsuit as one recent example of misuse of Britto art.

Officials at Apple and Craig & Karl did not immediately respond Monday to emails seeking comment.

entry.title: Apple Watch likely outsold all Android smartwatches already
entry.summary: Apple's website lists shipping times in June for some models, and four to six weeks for others, suggesting the company is straining to meet demand.

entry.title: WIRELESS SHOW HIGHLIGHTS: Eyes on Apple, BlackBerry
entry.summary: Apple is seeking to show that people can take quality images with iPhones, without needing to buy and carry a stand-alone camera.

entry.title: Analysts Say Apple Likely to Boost Production Quickly
entry.summary: Analysts widely expect the Apple Watch to outsell similar watches offered by Samsung Electronics Co Ltd, Sony Corp and LG Electronics, which have attracted lukewarm interest from consumers.

entry.title: Analysts Say Apple Likely to Boost Production Quickly
entry.summary: Despite mixed reviews, which praised the watch's styling but criticized its less-than-spectacular battery life and slow-loading apps, people flocked to Apple's stores to get a close-up look.

entry.title: Apple likely to boost watch production quickly: analysts
entry.summary:
According to shopping data firm Slice Intelligence, Apple booked nearly 1 million pre-orders for the Apple Watch in the United States on Friday.

The Apple Watch, which allows users to check email, listen to music and make phone calls when paired with an iPhone, goes on sale officially on April 24.

Munster, who expects Apple to sell 2.3 million watches in the April-June quarter, expects Apple to ramp production between mid-May and June.

entry.title: Apple likely to boost watch production quickly: analysts
entry.summary: (Reuters) - Apple Inc (AAPL.O) is likely to quickly ramp production of the Apple Watch after strong pre-orders outstripped limited supply in the first weekend following its launch, some Wall Street analysts said.

entry.title: Apple Watch US pre-orders estimated at 1M
entry.summary: Using e-receipt data, the company said that 957,000 people in the U.S. placed orders for an Apple Watch on the first day it became available.

entry.title: Apple trying to entice musicians?including Taylor Swift into deals for Beats streaming
entry.summary: Apple has also approached Taylor Swift and others about partnerships, the report said.

entry.title: Backlogged orders as shoppers get close-up look at Apple Watch
entry.summary: At Apple's flagship store in New York, Jack Weber, who was visiting from Charlottesville, Virginia, said he would give his wife a top-of-the-line "Edition" as a 50th-anniversary gift.

entry.title: Backlogged orders as shoppers get close-up look at Apple Watch
entry.summary:
But soon after online preorders opened on Friday, Apple's website listed shipping times in June for some models of the watch and four to six weeks for others.

At a San Francisco Apple store, dozens of customers crowded around newly installed wooden cabinets, snapping pictures of the gadgets on display under glass.

entry.title: Review: Many choices, indecision with Apple Watch
entry.summary: I didn't have good answers as my Apple Watch try-on visits started - at first modestly, with models that cost about the same as an iPhone.

entry.title: China?s knock-off Apple Watch fans

entry.title: Latest on Apple Watch release: Where to try on gold watch
entry.summary: Software apps and Internet services were a vital part of the iPhone's success, and Apple has made sure the new watch will have a wide range of apps available from the start.

entry.title: Latest on Apple Watch release: Where to try on gold watch
entry.summary:
All Apple stores will have these luxury versions on display, but only a handful let customers try them on.

Edition is available in 34 stores outside the U.S., including three non-Apple department stores with sections dedicated to Apple Watch.

entry.title: Backlogged orders as shoppers get close-up look at Apple Watch
entry.summary: People flocked to Apple's stores around the world to get a close-up look at the Apple Watch, the tech company's foray into the personal luxury goods market, with Apple predicting demand would exceed supply at product launch.

entry.title: Online excitement but no long lines for Apple Watch debut
entry.summary: In this photo taken with a fisheye lens, customers listen as an Apple employee points toward Apple's new watch, in San Francisco, Friday, April 10, 2015.

entry.title: Backlogged orders as shoppers get close-up look at Apple Watch
entry.summary: Apple predicted on Thursday that demand would exceed supply at product launch.

entry.title: Online excitement but no long lines for Apple Watch debut
entry.summary:
Eager customers placed online orders for the Apple Watch as soon as Apple's website began accepting them, shortly after midnight Pacific Time.

By midmorning, Apple's website was showing the earliest shipping date for many watch models would be in June or later.

Student Victor Leung was grinning from ear to ear after finishing his watch appointment and placing his order for a lower-priced sport model at the Apple store on New York's 5th Avenue.

Jack Weber, a retired University of Virginia professor, said he woke up at 3 a.m. to order a $1,000 stainless steel Apple Watch online.

entry.title: Latest on Apple Watch release: Where to try on gold watch
entry.summary:
The luxury versions of Apple Watch, known as Edition, have price tags ranging from $10,000 to $17,000.

Along with a host of Apple-designed apps, such as Maps, Mail, Siri and Apple Pay, watch owners will be able to download numerous apps developed by outside companies.

entry.title: Latest on Apple Watch release: Where to try on gold watch
entry.summary: Customers wear demo versions of Apple's new watch, which could only be bought pre-order online, Friday, April 10, 2015, in New York.

entry.title: Raymond James analyst says Apple Watch is a 'risk,' downgrades shares with stock near highs
entry.summary: "Early reviews on Apple Watch suggest it will fall far short of the 'insanely great' benchmark, at least in this first iteration," he said.

entry.title: Analyst downgrades Apple shares as smartwatch goes on sale
entry.summary:
While sales of the Apple Watch won't be a big part of the company's earnings for some time, McCourt said reviews have not been great and investors may start to worry that the company is going to struggle with launching new products.

While Apple has launched several new versions of the iPhone in Cook's nearly four-year tenure as CEO, the Apple Watch is its first entirely new product in that time.

Consumers were allowed to pre-order the Apple Watch starting at 3 a.m. Eastern time on Friday.

entry.title: Shoppers get to know Apple Watch on first day of sales
entry.summary: "It was beautifully made, like an expensive watch," says Li Hao, 27, a Web designer who owns a Mac, an iPad and an Apple TV.

entry.title: Apple Watch pre-orders begin, luxury US$17K gold model sells out in China in under an hour
entry.summary:
Testing Apple's mastery of consumer trends, the watch is an untried concept for the California-based company.

"Apple will outsell its wearable rivals by a very wide margin but it will do this on the power of its brand and its design alone," independent technology analyst Richard Windsor said.

entry.title: Latest on Apple Watch release: Trying it on
entry.summary: Employees of the Lenox Square Mall's Apple store in Atlanta clapped and cheered as customers streamed through its glass doors just before 10 a.m. About 20 people had lined up outside the second-floor storefront.

entry.title: Latest on Apple Watch release: Shopping begins
entry.summary:
If you haven't already ordered an Apple Watch, don't expect to get one when it starts shipping on April 24.

Apple's store in the U.S. is citing delivery of June or "4-6 weeks" for most models, including large expensive luxury versions with leather bands.

When Apple has done advance orders in the past, it makes inventory available in stores for launch day - in this case, April 24.

The 48-year old plumber knew which Apple Watch he wanted - the large Sport version with a black band for $399 - but he came to an Apple store rather than order online so that staff could walk him through it.

entry.title: Latest on Apple Watch release: Shoppers get personal
entry.summary: As Apple's 5th Avenue store in New York City prepares to open, journalists and Apple employees outnumber people waiting for the watch.

entry.title: Apple Watch makes its debut: Try-on visits, online orders begin
entry.summary: In London's Covent Garden, a tourist hotspot, a buzz is growing in the Apple flagship store as dozens of fans come to check out the new Apple Watch.

entry.title: Latest on Apple Watch release: Shoppers get personal
entry.summary:
Apple hasn't offered any estimates of how many watches it expects to sell, but some analysts have predicted sales could reach 10 million to 20 million units in the first year.

Veteran Apple watcher Gene Munster, an analyst at Piper Jaffray, has offered a more conservative estimate of 8 million.

By comparison, Apple sold more than 10 million of its new iPhone 6 and 6 Plus smartphones in the first weekend they were available in September, and a record total of 74.5 million iPhones in the fourth quarter of last year.

entry.title: APPLE WATCH LIVE: Try-on visits, online orders begin
entry.summary:
The curious in Japan formed a long line in Isetan department store, where a special section was built just for the Apple watch.

China was among countries where the watch had its global debut Friday, reflecting the country's fast-growing status as one of Apple's most important markets.

entry.title: In China, knock-off Apple Watches have their own fans
entry.summary:
"It came on sale in mid-March and has been constantly out of stock," said one imitation Apple Watch seller who declined to give his name.

At her store, one was retailing for 360 yuan ($58) - around one eighth of the cost of Apple's cheaper Watch models.

On Friday, Apple, the world's most valuable technology company, started previewing the Apple Watch, its first new gadget line since former CEO Steve Jobs died in 2011.

In Hong Kong, the official Apple Store preview of the Watch was quiet.

entry.title: APPLE WATCH LIVE: Try-on visits, online orders begin
entry.summary: A customer picks up an Apple Watch at an Apple Store in Hong Kong Friday, April 10, 2015.

entry.title: APPLE WATCH LIVE: Try-on visits, online orders begin

entry.title: APPLE WATCH LIVE: Try-on visits, online orders begin
entry.summary: In central Shanghai, potential Apple watch buyers stood in lines two to five people long over their lunch hour at an Apple store on Friday to try on the watch many said they already planned to buy.

entry.title: Apple Watch on show as pre-ordering starts: live
entry.summary: Visitors to Apple retail stores in the UK will be able to preview and then try on the Watch - by appointment - before pre-ordering one of the three Watch collection, that start at 299, but go up to more than 13,000 in price.

entry.title: Strong turnout for world's first glimpse at Apple Watch
entry.summary:
The Apple Watch sport starts at $349 while the standard version comes in at $549 in the U.S. High-end "Edition" watches with 18-karat gold alloys are priced from $10,000 and go as high as $17,000.

At the Apple Store in Omotesando, a high-end shopping district in the heart of Tokyo, dozens of shoppers huddled around two glass displays, snapping pictures of the range of options available on the different watch models.

entry.title: Strong turnout for world's first glimpse at Apple Watch
entry.summary:
A spokesman for Apple in Sydney declined to comment on the memo, citing company policy.

Apple shares closed 0.76 percent higher at $126.56 on Thursday.

entry.title: Strong turnout in Australia for first glimpse at Apple Watch
entry.summary:
"I feel naked without a watch. I think I will buy the Apple watch with the sports band ... I'm working very hard right now so I can buy this watch," Bock told Reuters.

"This is just Apple's interpretation of the watch, I don't think watch makers should be worried at all," Stephen Fenech, editor of the Tech Guide website, told Reuters.

entry.title: Apple expects strong demand in smartwatch consumer debut
entry.summary:
The Apple Watch, which also marks the Cupertino, California company's debut in a fledgling wearable technology market, will be available for pre-order online and to try out in stores - but not take home.

Still, Apple's watch is widely expected to outsell those by Samsung, Sony (6758.T) and Fitbit, that have attracted modest interest from consumers.

entry.title: Apple expects strong demand in smartwatch consumer debut
entry.summary: Underscoring its strategy to market the watch as a fashion accessory, Apple is selling it through a handful of high-end stores including Selfridges in London, Galeries Lafayette in Paris and Tokyo's Isetan department store.

entry.title: With primetime TV, Apple hopes to hook customers for new Watch
entry.summary: "Apple occupies 13 percent of spending in the smartphone category, while generating 40 percent of the buzz garnered from TV ads", said Sean Muller, CEO of iSpot.tv.

entry.title: With primetime TV, Apple hopes to hook customers for new Watch
entry.summary:
That's a little less than the $42 million Apple spent over the past five months on TV ads for the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus.

Starting Friday, the Apple Watch will be available for preview in stores and preorder on the Internet ahead of its April 24 on-sale date.

Data also showed that Apple Watch advert airings were ramped up on Monday this week, capitalizing on a widely viewed NCAA final between Duke and Wisconsin.

entry.title: With primetime TV, Apple hopes to hook customers for new Watch
entry.summary:
"The iPhone 6 was a barn burner from the get-go. But with the Apple Watch, which is new product category with less familiarity, it makes sense that they'd go after it with more intensity," said JMP analyst Alex Gauna.

Apple's device will likely account for 55 percent of global smartwatch shipments this year in a market worth about $11 billion, according to market analysis group Societe Generale.

entry.title: Apple Watch isn't the only gadget out this week

entry.title: Apple Watch options: 54 combinations of case, band, size
entry.summary:
To help you choose, Apple has plenty of videos on its website and Apple Store and Apple Watch apps.

The Apple Store app also has sizing guides, images of the watch cases in actual size and animation of buckles and clasps, which you can open and close by pinching in and out.

entry.title: Apple Watch options: 54 combinations of case, band, size
entry.summary: Apple Watch, available for pre-order on Friday, April 10, comes with a choice of watch case, band and size _ there are 54 possible configurations in all.

entry.title: Apple: if you want to buy a Watch, stay at home
entry.summary: "To provide the best experience and selection to as many customers as we can, we will be taking orders for Apple Watch exclusively online during the initial launch period."

entry.title: Apple Watch shortages expected, Apple says
entry.summary: Based on a survey in the United States on consumer interest in buying the Apple Watch, BMO Capital Markets has cut its estimate for sales to 39 million units though September 2016.

entry.title: Your guide to trying on, ordering Apple Watch
entry.summary: However, the watch will be available to try on at Galeries Lafayette in Paris, Isetan in Tokyo, Selfridges in London and some Apple resellers in China and Japan starting Friday.

entry.title: Your guide to trying on, ordering Apple Watch
entry.summary:
No smartwatch has gotten as much attention as the Apple Watch, given Apple's devoted fan base and the company's knack for designing products consumers can't live without.

Apple's 24-hour store on New York's Fifth Avenue will close temporarily to set up the displays; it will reopen at 9 a.m. Friday.

entry.title: Your guide to trying on, ordering Apple Watch
entry.summary:
Starting Friday, Apple Store staff will be able to help you choose from the array of options.

Apple will start taking reservations through its website at 12:01 a.m. PDT Friday as well.

entry.title: Slow apps, low battery life limit appeal of Apple Watch: reviewers
entry.summary:
(Reuters) - Apple Inc's (AAPL.O) "beautiful" and "stylish" smartwatch could make life easier for people on the move, reviewers say, but the gadget gets poor marks for battery life and slow-loading apps.

Reviews published on Wednesday made much of the device's relatively poor battery life - up to 18 hours, according to Apple - and said its apps will need upgrades to load more quickly.

Loading an app required the watch to pull tremendous amounts of data from iPhones, Patel said, adding that Apple had told him upcoming software updates would address performance issues.

Analysts at Societe Generale said they expected Apple to sell 8 million watches in 2015, contributing about 1.7 percent or $4 billion to Apple's total sales.

entry.summary: The new MacBook comes in silver, gold or gray - the first time there has been a color choice since Apple ditched plastic for metal on its laptops.

entry.title: Apple Watch isn't the only gadget out this week
entry.summary:
Apple borrowed many design techniques from the iPad, including eliminating the fan.

Initially, it's available only to owners of an Apple TV, iPhone or iPad, or to Cablevision's Internet-access subscribers.

Apple store employees will show you the range of options, including different watch cases, bands and sizes.

Apple's new laptop, simply called MacBook, debuts Friday.

entry.title: Apple Watch review round-up

"Apple Watch is light-years better than any of the feeble, clunky efforts that have come before it."

"But among smartwatches, Apple Watch is second to none."

entry.title: Apple's iOS 8.3 Update Is Here
Apple Watch stylish but not for everyone, reviewers say
entry.summary:
"The Apple Watch is cool, it's beautiful, it's powerful and it's easy to use. But it's not essential. Not yet."

As Manjoo concluded: "The first Apple Watch may not be for you -- but someday soon, it will change your world."

But, he said, "the Apple Watch isn't quite the gatekeeper to my digital life that I wanted. Take app alerts -- there's a fine line between being in the know and having your wrist jiggle all day."

entry.title: Apple Watch stylish but not for everyone, reviewers say
entry.summary:
"After using it, I had no question that the Apple Watch is the most advanced piece of wearable technology you can buy today," Bloomberg's Josh Topolsky wrote.

But, according to New York Times tech columnist Farhad Manjoo, while he generally liked the Apple Watch after a "steep" learning curve, the third-party apps available for the device are "mostly useless right now."

entry.title: Slow apps, low battery life limit appeal of Apple Watch-reviewers
entry.summary: But the software is "initially complex" and not suited to tech novices - unusual for an Apple device, said Farhad Manjoo, who reviewed the watch for the New York Times.

entry.title: Reviews are in: Apple Watch performs well but isn't a necessity
entry.summary:
Yahoo Tech: "Once you get to know the Watch, you realize that Apple carefully observed its rivals' failures, and adjusted its product accordingly."

CNET: "The Apple Watch is the most ambitious, well-constructed smartwatch ever seen, but first-gen shortfalls make it feel more like a fashionable toy than a necessary tool."

entry.title: Early Apple Watch reviews are mixed
entry.summary: Wall Street Journal: "After over a week of living with Apple's latest gadget on my wrist, I realized the company isn't just selling some wrist-worn computer, it's selling good looks and coolness, with some bonus computer features. Too many features that are too hard to find, if you ask me."

entry.title: Apple Watch pros and cons: What reviewers are saying
entry.summary: Apple Inc's smartwatch is a "beautiful", "stylish" and "elegantly made" piece of technology that could make life easier for people on the move, reviewers said, but it also has shortcomings and a price that could limit its appeal.

entry.title: Apple Watch sleek and stylish but not for everyone, reviewers say
entry.summary:
"For now, the Apple Watch is for pioneers," the Wall Street Journal's Geoffrey Fowler wrote.

Most reviews, while praising the watch's sleek design, highlighted its relatively short battery life - up to 18 hours, according to Apple.

CNET's Stein said Apple wants people to see the Apple Watch as "fine jewelry."

entry.title: The first wearable you'll actually want to wear - and the answer to obsessively checking your mobile: Dailymail.com's verdict on the Apple Watch
entry.summary: Apple says over 1,000 apps have now been submitted for the Watch.

entry.title: Apple Watch review: Youll want one, but you dont need one
entry.summary: So Apple has succeeded in its first big task with its watch.

entry.title: Let's review the reviews of Apple Watch
Apple faces local battles as its prepares global payments push
entry.summary:
Apple Pay has taken the United States by storm since its launch in September, and the company has said it already accounts for around $2 out of every $3 spent using "contactless" payments on the three big U.S. card networks.

Unlike the consumer electronics business where Apple regularly rolls out new computers or phones in dozens of countries at once, there is no such thing as a unified payments market.

Apple Pay allows consumers using new Apple phones, tablets and smartwatches to buy goods by simply holding the device up to readers installed by store merchants.

Meanwhile, major banks are looking to offer "mobile wallet" payment apps of their own, using some of the same security technology popularized by Apple.

entry.title: Apple faces local battles as its prepares global payments push
entry.summary:
"Apple doesn't need blanket coverage to start," Morgan Stanley's Humphrey said.

"Apple Pay is available in the U.S.," the official site simply states.

Credit card companies such as Visa and MasterCard - which provided crucial early backing to Apple Pay and are gearing up to support its international expansion - are also looking to hedge their bets and back viable alternatives.

Analysts say Apple is likely to go after markets where iPhones are already popular and where wireless payment readers using technology on which Apple relies are widely available.

entry.title: Apple, Google, Microsoft cop tax audit
entry.summary:
Technology giants Apple, Google and Microsoft have told the federal inquiry into corporate tax avoidance that they are being audited by the tax office for alleged tax avoidance.

Apple Australia managing director Tony King.

entry.title: Review: New Apple Photos app makes fixing, cropping easy
entry.summary:
Apple's new Photos app for Mac computers, available Wednesday as a free software update, makes it easy to organize and edit your pictures.

You may need to buy more iCloud storage through Apple, as the 5 free gigabytes only translates to roughly 3,000 iPhone photos, not to mention video or larger files from stand-alone cameras.

entry.title: Things to know about Apple's new photo-storage service
entry.summary: You can also access your photos on Windows computers with Apple's free iCloud for Windows software.

entry.title: Apple joins blue-chip Dow index; AT&T gets booted
entry.summary:
S&P Dow Jones Indices said the decision to fold in Apple won't alter the overall level of the index, which stood at 17,856 Friday.

Apple won't get top billing in the Dow, though.

entry.title: HBO Now streaming service launches on Apple products
entry.summary: Apple, in an effort to woo new customers, lowered the price of its Apple TV device to $69.

entry.title: HBO Now streaming service launches on Apple products
entry.summary: The groundbreaking move has been anticipated since HBO Chief Executive Richard Plepler unveiled the service during an Apple product conference last month in San Francisco.

entry.title: HBO Now streaming service launches on Apple products
entry.summary: HBO Now, the stand-alone streaming service, launched Tuesday morning on Apple products, HBO said.

entry.title: Snowden: CIA tried to hack Apple devices for nearly a decade
entry.summary:
Efforts to break into Apple products by government security researchers started as early as 2006, a year before Apple introduced its first iPhone and continued through the launch of the iPad in 2010 and beyond, The Intercept said.

Last September, Apple strengthened encryption methods for data stored on iPhones, saying the changes meant the company no longer had any way to extract customer data on the devices, even if a government ordered it to with a search warrant.

entry.title: Liking Apple too much a big problem for fund managers

A February 2015 IDC report placed Android at 81.5% global market share in 2014 against Apple s 14.8%.

An apple a day might keep the pharmacist away: study
entry.summary:
And at first blush, apple eaters seemed more likely to keep the doctor away, with fewer self-reported visits to health care providers.

Limitations of the study include its reliance on self-reports of apple consumption, doctor visits and prescriptions.

entry.title: An apple a day may not keep the doctor away, study says
entry.summary:
That's according to proverb-busting research that found daily apple eaters had just as many doctor visits as those who ate fewer or no apples.

Apple eaters were slightly less likely to use prescription drugs, but the study lacks information on use of over-the-counter medication and alternative medicine.

Apples are a good source of vitamin C; one medium apple has about 100 calories and provides nearly 20 percent of the daily recommended amount of fiber.

But, said Dr. Steven Zeisel, director of the University of North Carolina's Nutrition Research Institute, "One apple isn't going to be enough to make a difference unless it's part of a healthy food pattern."

entry.title: An apple a day may not keep the doctor away, study says
entry.summary:
A preliminary analysis found apple eaters had slightly fewer visits than apple avoiders - those who ate less than one daily or no apples.

About 9 percent of adults studied ate the equivalent of at least one small apple daily.

Those who ate less than that were considered apple shunners.

Apple eaters had more education and were less likely to smoke than apple shunners, and fewer of them were white.

entry.title: Will the Apple Watch finally move the needle in the smartwatch industry? Here's why & why not
entry.summary:
The stakes are big for Apple CEO Tim Cook: the watch is the first brand-new Apple product to be launched without legendary co-founder Steve Jobs.

MORE FEATURES THAN RIVALS: Along with email, texts and phone calls, Apple says its watch will present news, health readings and other notifications in creative ways that can be read at a glance.

While affluent consumers might pay that for a watch they can wear for years, or even hand down to their children, it's a lot of money for something that could become outdated if Apple releases a new model every year or so - as it does with smartphones.

Apple is working with outside companies to create more apps; Cook has talked about using the watch as an electronic "key" for hotel doors or even cars.

entry.title: Apple's Tim Cook to donate his wealth - Fortune

entry.title: The last days of Steve Jobs: New biography reveals how ailing Apple CEO invited his successor Tim Cook to watch a sappy football film on the eve of his death and how Bill Gates paid one final visit to talk shop
entry.summary: Cook, who took the reins of Apple in August 2011, less than two months before his mentor's death, described to the authors of the biography the moment Jobs invited him over to his house to offer him the top job.

entry.title: Last days of Steve Jobs: Apple CEO invited Tim Cook to watch Denzel Washington movie week before he died
entry.summary:
Five days after Cook and Jobs' movie night, the co-founder of Apple passed away at his Palo Alto, California, estate from complications from pancreatic cancer.

In an interesting titbit, the book reveals that Jobs' favorite Beatle was John Lennon, and that he reportedly named his company after Beatles' Apple Corps Record.

The two men bonded over how much they both missed Jobs, and Lasseter confided in the new Apple CEO that he still had his late boss' number on his phone.

In the memoir, which was released this week, Tim Cook did not miss an opportunity to take a swipe at the unauthorized Steve Jobs biography by Walter Isaacson, which debuted just weeks after the Apple co-founder's death.

entry.title: Apple stock starts trading as part of Dow today
entry.summary:
Apple Inc. was added to the Dow after the market closed Wednesday.

The Dow will begin trading with Apple stock when the markets open Thursday.

Apple, based in Cupertino, California, has a market value of $748 billion.

entry.title: U.S. poll shows 40 per cent of iPhone owners would buy Apple Watch
entry.summary:
About 40 percent of adult Apple iPhone owners in the United States are interested in buying the company's new Apple Watch, according to a new Reuters/Ipsos poll.

Discussions about the watch have flooded online social media channels such as Twitter and Facebook since Apple held a splashy event in San Francisco on March 9 to showcase the watch.

Among the conversations relating to the Apple watch during the one-week period, 5.8 per cent of the comments showed an intent to purchase, according to Networked Insights, which analyzes tweets, public Facebook posts and other sources.

entry.title: Nearly 40 percent of iPhone owners interested in Apple Watch: poll
entry.summary:
Social media chatter about the Apple watch was 15 percent positive and 5 percent negative in the week following Apple's event, according to an analysis that the firm Networked Insights conducted for Reuters.

Apple is among several large tech companies looking to jumpstart a new market for "wearable" electronic devices.

entry.title: Nearly 40 percent of iPhone owners interested in Apple Watch: poll
entry.summary:
Owners of the iPhone are a particularly important market for Apple as it launches the new watch, which goes on sale April 24.

Among the iPhone owners, 39 percent were interested in purchasing the Apple watch, including 17 percent describing themselves as very interested.

By contrast, the social conversation for Apple's iPhone 6 during the same week was 5 percent positive and 0 percent negative, according to the analysis.

entry.title: Apple in talks to launch online TV service: Report
entry.summary:
The tech giant is working with programmers to offer a bundled service of about 25 channels anchored by broadcasters like ABC, CBS and Fox, on devices such as Apple TV.

The service will not offer NBC broadcast network and cable channels such as USA and Bravo, after a fallout between Apple and Comcast, parent of NBC and CNBC, the report said.

entry.title: Liking Apple too much a big problem for fund managers
entry.summary:
Yet that devotion for Apple is a problem for Burnham and some other managers of so-called diversified funds like his - they want more Apple than they can buy under self-imposed risk-reducing guidelines that typically have them holding no more than 5% of their assets in any one company.

Burnham and the 174 fund managers like him who hold large stakes of their diversified portfolios in Apple are pulled in two directions: hoping to prevent an unforeseen drop in Apple shares from upending their portfolios, while also benefiting from a company whose shares are up 12% this year so far.

Burham didn't set out to have such a big stake in Apple, he said.

Other fund managers with large stakes in Apple who aren't selling say that they didn't set out to have an oversized position in the company.

David Chiueh, the manager of the Upright Growth fund, has 13.4% in Apple, the second-largest among diversified funds tracked by Lipper, mostly because shares he bought in 2008 have appreciated, he said.

entry.title: Apple Watch may be a tough sell with Americans: 69% not interested in buying the gadget, new poll shows

entry.title: 3 reasons Apple's watch will _ or won't _ change the game

Is the Apple Watch going to be able to do the same?

Here are three reasons the Apple Watch will finally move the needle in the smartwatch industry - and three reasons it might not.

A recent Forrester survey found some respondents didn't see a reason to buy one because they already owned a less-expensive fitness band or a full-featured smartphone (although it also found Apple fans ready to buy the new watch).
